title: 109_s1098
content:
The "Student Loan Abuse Prevention Act of 2005" aims to end unnecessary taxpayer subsidies for lenders in the Federal Family Education Loan Program, provide free public college tuition for future math, science, and special education teachers, and offer additional assistance to students eligible for Federal Pell Grants. The Taxpayer-Teacher Protection Act of 2004 is amended to include provisions related to the Higher Education Act of 1965. Specifically, changes are made to Section 438(b)(2)(B) regarding special allowances for student loans. The Taxpayer-Teacher Protection Act of 2004 is amended to include provisions related to the Higher Education Act of 1965, specifically changes to Section 438(b)(2)(B) regarding special allowances for student loans originated, transferred, or purchased after the enactment date. The Taxpayer-Teacher Protection Act of 2004 amended Section 438(b)(2)(B) of the Higher Education Act of 1965, affecting special allowances for student loans originated, transferred, or purchased after the enactment date. The Taxpayer-Teacher Protection Act of 2004 amended special allowances for student loans under the Higher Education Act of 1965, encouraging borrowers to consolidate loans if the holder is entitled to a special allowance. The Taxpayer-Teacher Protection Act of 2004 amended special allowances for student loans under the Higher Education Act of 1965, encouraging borrowers to consolidate loans by offering incentives such as an immediate $1,000 reduction in the loan principal or a 1-percent reduction in the interest rate. The Secretary of Education may offer incentives to borrowers to consolidate loans, including a 1-percent reduction in interest rate payments, but not if it increases long-term costs to the Federal Government. SEC. 4. Tuition-free college for future mathematics, science, and special education teachers. Increases loan amounts for teachers in these fields. Effective date is for new borrowers on or after October 1, 1998.

SEC. 5. Increased grant aid to Pell Grant recipients. The Secretary of Education will use funds from reduced expenditures for loan cancellation and forgiveness for teachers. Any remaining funds will be used to make payments to nonprofit lenders based on their 2005 funding levels. Nonprofit lenders will receive payments based on their 2005 funding levels, with specific requirements such as being a 501(c)(3) organization and not exceeding salary and benefits limits for employees. The Department of Education provides salary and benefits to the Secretary of Education. Nonprofit lenders must not pass on revenue to for-profit entities or offer benefits based on a borrower's participation in certain programs under the Higher Education Act. The nonprofit lender must use payments received to provide grant or scholarship benefits to students eligible for Federal Pell Grants under the Higher Education Act of 1965. The lender must also be subject to public oversight through a State charter or at least 50% oversight. The nonprofit lender must not market programs under part B of title IV of the Higher Education Act of 1965 compared to part D programs, or promote loans from for-profit lenders. The nonprofit lender is prohibited from promoting loans from for-profit lenders and must provide basic information on lenders under part B of title IV of the Higher Education Act of 1965.
